SUMMARY: N-acetylgalactosamine repressor, AgaR, negatively controls expression of aga gene cluster, which is involved in transport and catabolism of N-acetylgalactosamine and d-galactosamine [14731281, 10931310]. It is negatively autoregulated and coordinately represses transcription of divergent agaZVWEFA operon, which is related to transport and degradation of N-acetylgalactosamine [14731281]. This repressor responds to N-acetylgalactosamine and d-galactosamine in medium. As a member of DeoR/GlpR family of transcriptional regulators [14731281]. AgaR features an N-terminal domain containing a helix-turn-helix motif and a C-terminal domain that includes key residues involved in co-inducer recognition and oligomerization [14731281]. In accordance with or helix-turn-helix DNA-binding repressors, AgaR may bind to DNA as a tetramer. AgaR binds in tandem to several repeat sequences in intergenic regions of agaZp, agaRp, and agaSp to repress transcription by overlapping -35 and -10 boxes. binding targets for AgaR consist of 24-nucleotide-long repeat sequences that possess conserved motifs [14731281]. agaR: N-acetylglactosamine degradation [8932697].
